<p>Conversely, if the variance of a random variable is 0, then it is <a href="/wiki/Almost_surely" title="Almost surely">almost surely</a> a constant. That is, it always has the same value:
</p>
<dl><dd><span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \operatorname {Var} (X)=0\iff \exists a:P(X=a)=1.}">
  <semantics>
    <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
      <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
        <mi>Var</mi>
        <mo>⁡<!-- ⁡ --></mo>
        <mo stretchy="false">(</mo>
        <mi>X</mi>
        <mo stretchy="false">)</mo>
        <mo>=</mo>
        <mn>0</mn>
        <mspace width="thickmathspace"></mspace>
        <mo stretchy="false">⟺<!-- ⟺ --></mo>
        <mspace width="thickmathspace"></mspace>
        <mi mathvariant="normal">∃<!-- ∃ --></mi>
        <mi>a</mi>
        <mo>:</mo>
        <mi>P</mi>
        <mo stretchy="false">(</mo>
        <mi>X</mi>
        <mo>=</mo>
        <mi>a</mi>
        <mo stretchy="false">)</mo>
        <mo>=</mo>
        <mn>1.</mn>

    </mrow>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Issues_of_finiteness">Issues of finiteness</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=Variance&action=edit&section=10" title="Edit section: Issues of finiteness" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>If a distribution does not have a finite expected value, as is the case for the <a href="/wiki/Cauchy_distribution" title="Cauchy distribution">Cauchy distribution</a>, then the variance cannot be finite either. However, some distributions may not have a finite variance, despite their expected value being finite. An example is a <a href="/wiki/Pareto_distribution" title="Pareto distribution">Pareto distribution</a> whose <a href="/wiki/Pareto_index" title="Pareto index">index</a> <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle k}">
  <semantics>
    <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
      <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
        <mi>k</mi>
      </mstyle>
    </mrow>

<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Units_of_measurement">Units of measurement</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=Variance&action=edit&section=14" title="Edit section: Units of measurement" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>Unlike the <a href="/wiki/Average_absolute_deviation" title="Average absolute deviation">expected absolute deviation</a>, the variance of a variable has units that are the square of the units of the variable itself.  For example, a variable measured in meters will have a variance measured in meters squared.  For this reason, describing data sets via their <a href="/wiki/Standard_deviation" title="Standard deviation">standard deviation</a> or <a href="/wiki/Root_mean_square_deviation" title="Root mean square deviation">root mean square deviation</a> is often preferred over using the variance.  In the dice example the standard deviation is <span class="texhtml"><span class="nowrap">√<span style="border-top:1px solid; padding:0 0.1em;">2.9</span></span> ≈ 1.7</span>, slightly larger than the expected absolute deviation of 1.5.
</p><p>The standard deviation and the expected absolute deviation can both be used as an indicator of the "spread" of a distribution.  The standard deviation is more amenable to algebraic manipulation than the expected absolute deviation, and, together with variance and its generalization <a href="/wiki/Covariance" title="Covariance">covariance</a>, is used frequently in theoretical statistics; however the expected absolute deviation tends to be more <a href="/wiki/Robust_statistics" title="Robust statistics">robust</a> as it is less sensitive to <a href="/wiki/Outlier" title="Outlier">outliers</a> arising from <a href="/wiki/Measurement_error" class="mw-redirect" title="Measurement error">measurement anomalies</a> or an unduly <a href="/wiki/Heavy-tailed_distribution" title="Heavy-tailed distribution">heavy-tailed distribution</a>.
</p>

<p>There are cases when a sample is taken without knowing, in advance, how many observations will be acceptable according to some criterion. In such cases, the sample size <span class="texhtml">N</span> is a random variable whose variation adds to the variation of <span class="texhtml">X</span>, such that,
</p>

<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=Variance&action=edit&section=29" title="Edit section: Population variance and sample variance" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">

</div><section class="mf-section-5 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-5">
<p><span class="anchor" id="Estimation"></span>
</p>
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Unbiased_estimation_of_standard_deviation" title="Unbiased estimation of standard deviation">Unbiased estimation of standard deviation</a></div>
<p>Real-world observations such as the measurements of yesterday's rain throughout the day typically cannot be complete sets of all possible observations that could be made. As such, the variance calculated from the finite set will in general not match the variance that would have been calculated from the full population of possible observations. This means that one <a href="/wiki/Estimation_theory" title="Estimation theory">estimates</a> the mean and variance from a limited set of observations by using an <a href="/wiki/Estimator" title="Estimator">estimator</a> equation. The estimator is a function of the <a href="/wiki/Sample_(statistics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sample (statistics)">sample</a> of <i>n</i> <a href="/wiki/Observations" class="mw-redirect" title="Observations">observations</a> drawn without observational bias from the whole <a href="/wiki/Statistical_population" title="Statistical population">population</a> of potential observations. In this example, the sample would be the set of actual measurements of yesterday's rainfall from available rain gauges within the geography of interest.
</p><p>The simplest estimators for population mean and population variance are simply the mean and variance of the sample, the <b>sample mean</b> and <b>(uncorrected) sample variance</b> – these are <a href="/wiki/Consistent_estimator" title="Consistent estimator">consistent estimators</a> (they converge to the value of the whole population as the number of samples increases) but can be improved. Most simply, the sample variance is computed as the sum of <a href="/wiki/Squared_deviations" class="mw-redirect" title="Squared deviations">squared deviations</a> about the (sample) mean, divided by <i>n</i> as the number of samples<i>.</i> However, using values other than <i>n</i> improves the estimator in various ways. Four common values for the denominator are <i>n,</i> <i>n</i> − 1, <i>n</i> + 1, and <i>n</i> − 1.5: <i>n</i> is the simplest (the variance of the sample), <i>n</i> − 1 eliminates bias,<sup id="cite_ref-bessel_10-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bessel-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> <i>n</i> + 1 minimizes <a href="/wiki/Mean_squared_error" title="Mean squared error">mean squared error</a> for the normal distribution,<sup id="cite_ref-Kourouklis_11-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kourouklis-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> and <i>n</i> − 1.5 mostly eliminates bias in <a href="/wiki/Unbiased_estimation_of_standard_deviation" title="Unbiased estimation of standard deviation">unbiased estimation of standard deviation</a> for the normal distribution.<sup id="cite_ref-12" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-12"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>12<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p><p>Firstly, if the true population mean is unknown, then the sample variance (which uses the sample mean in place of the true mean) is a <a href="/wiki/Biased_estimator" class="mw-redirect" title="Biased estimator">biased estimator</a>: it underestimates the variance by a factor of (<i>n</i> − 1) / <i>n</i>; correcting this factor, resulting in the sum of squared deviations about the sample mean divided by <i>n</i> -1 instead of <i>n</i>, is called <i><a href="/wiki/Bessel%27s_correction" title="Bessel's correction">Bessel's correction</a></i>.<sup id="cite_ref-bessel_10-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-bessel-10"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>10<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The resulting estimator is unbiased and is called the <b>(corrected) sample variance</b> or <b>unbiased sample variance</b>. If the mean is determined in some other way than from the same samples used to estimate the variance, then this bias does not arise, and the variance can safely be estimated as that of the samples about the (independently known) mean.
</p><p>Secondly, the sample variance does not generally minimize <a href="/wiki/Mean_squared_error" title="Mean squared error">mean squared error</a> between sample variance and population variance. Correcting for bias often makes this worse: one can always choose a scale factor that performs better than the corrected sample variance, though the optimal scale factor depends on the <a href="/wiki/Excess_kurtosis" class="mw-redirect" title="Excess kurtosis">excess kurtosis</a> of the population (see <a href="/wiki/Mean_squared_error#Variance" title="Mean squared error">mean squared error: variance</a>) and introduces bias. This always consists of scaling down the unbiased estimator (dividing by a number larger than <i>n</i> − 1) and is a simple example of a <a href="/wiki/Shrinkage_estimator" class="mw-redirect" title="Shrinkage estimator">shrinkage estimator</a>: one "shrinks" the unbiased estimator towards zero. For the normal distribution, dividing by <i>n</i> + 1 (instead of <i>n</i> − 1 or <i>n</i>) minimizes mean squared error.<sup id="cite_ref-Kourouklis_11-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-Kourouklis-11"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>11<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The resulting estimator is biased, however, and is known as the <b>biased sample variation</b>.
</p>
<div class="mw-heading mw-heading3"><h3 id="Population_variance">Population variance</h3><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=Variance&action=edit&section=30" title="Edit section: Population variance" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div>
<p>In general, the <i><b>population variance</b></i> of a <i>finite</i> <a href="/wiki/Statistical_population" title="Statistical population">population</a> of size <i>N</i> with values <i>x</i><sub><i>i</i></sub> is given by<span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-display mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math display="block" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle {\begin{aligned}\sigma ^{2}&={\frac {1}{N}}\sum _{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}-\mu \right)^{2}={\frac {1}{N}}\sum _{i=1}^{N}\left(x_{i}^{2}-2\mu x_{i}+\mu ^{2}\right)\\[5pt]&=\left({\frac {1}{N}}\sum _{i=1}^{N}x_{i}^{2}\right)-2\mu \left({\frac {1}{N}}\sum _{i=1}^{N}x_{i}\right)+\mu ^{2}\\[5pt]&=\operatorname {E} [x_{i}^{2}]-\mu ^{2}\end{aligned}}}">

<p>In many practical situations, the true variance of a population is not known <i>a priori</i> and must be computed somehow. When dealing with extremely large populations, it is not possible to count every object in the population, so the computation must be performed on a <a href="/wiki/Sample_(statistics)" class="mw-redirect" title="Sample (statistics)">sample</a> of the population.<sup id="cite_ref-14" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-14"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>14<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> This is generally referred to as <b>sample variance</b> or <b>empirical variance</b>. Sample variance can also be applied to the estimation of the variance of a continuous distribution from a sample of that distribution.

<p>Either estimator may be simply referred to as the <i>sample variance</i> when the version can be determined by context. The same proof is also applicable for samples taken from a continuous probability distribution.
</p><p>The use of the term <i>n</i> − 1 is called <a href="/wiki/Bessel%27s_correction" title="Bessel's correction">Bessel's correction</a>, and it is also used in <a href="/wiki/Sample_covariance" class="mw-redirect" title="Sample covariance">sample covariance</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Sample_standard_deviation" class="mw-redirect" title="Sample standard deviation">sample standard deviation</a> (the square root of variance). The square root is a <a href="/wiki/Concave_function" title="Concave function">concave function</a> and thus introduces negative bias (by <a href="/wiki/Jensen%27s_inequality" title="Jensen's inequality">Jensen's inequality</a>), which depends on the distribution, and thus the corrected sample standard deviation (using Bessel's correction) is biased. The <a href="/wiki/Unbiased_estimation_of_standard_deviation" title="Unbiased estimation of standard deviation">unbiased estimation of standard deviation</a> is a technically involved problem, though for the normal distribution using the term <i>n</i> − 1.5 yields an almost unbiased estimator.
</p><p>The unbiased sample variance is a <a href="/wiki/U-statistic" title="U-statistic">U-statistic</a> for the function <i>ƒ</i>(<i>y</i><sub>1</sub>, <i>y</i><sub>2</sub>) = (<i>y</i><sub>1</sub> − <i>y</i><sub>2</sub>)<sup>2</sup>/2, meaning that it is obtained by averaging a 2-sample statistic over 2-element subsets of the population.
</p>

<p>For a set of numbers {10, 15, 30, 45, 57, 52 63, 72, 81, 93, 102, 105}, if this set is the whole data population for some measurement, then variance is the population variance 932.743 as the sum of the squared deviations about the mean of this set, divided by 12 as the number of the set members. If the set is a sample from the whole population, then the unbiased sample variance can be calculated as 1017.538 that is the sum of the squared deviations about the mean of the sample, divided by 11 instead of 12. A function VAR.S in <a href="/wiki/Microsoft_Excel" title="Microsoft Excel">Microsoft Excel</a> gives the unbiased sample variance while VAR.P is for population variance.
</p>

</section><div class="mw-heading mw-heading2 section-heading" onclick="mfTempOpenSection(6)"><span class="indicator mf-icon mf-icon-expand mf-icon--small"></span><h2 id="Tests_of_equality_of_variances">Tests of equality of variances</h2><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=Variance&action=edit&section=38" title="Edit section: Tests of equality of variances" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">
    <span class="minerva-icon minerva-icon--edit"></span>
<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div><section class="mf-section-6 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-6">
<p>The <a href="/wiki/F-test_of_equality_of_variances" title="F-test of equality of variances">F-test of equality of variances</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Chi_square_test" class="mw-redirect" title="Chi square test">chi square tests</a> are adequate when the sample is normally distributed. Non-normality makes testing for the equality of two or more variances more difficult.
</p><p>Several non parametric tests have been proposed: these include the Barton–David–Ansari–Freund–Siegel–Tukey test, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Capon_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Capon test (page does not exist)">Capon test</a>, <a href="/wiki/Mood_test" class="mw-redirect" title="Mood test">Mood test</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Klotz_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Klotz test (page does not exist)">Klotz test</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Sukhatme_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Sukhatme test (page does not exist)">Sukhatme test</a>. The Sukhatme test applies to two variances and requires that both <a href="/wiki/Median" title="Median">medians</a> be known and equal to zero. The Mood, Klotz, Capon and Barton–David–Ansari–Freund–Siegel–Tukey tests also apply to two variances. They allow the median to be unknown but do require that the two medians are equal.
</p><p>The <a href="/w/index.php?title=Lehmann_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Lehmann test (page does not exist)">Lehmann test</a> is a parametric test of two variances. Of this test there are several variants known. Other tests of the equality of variances include the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Box_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Box test (page does not exist)">Box test</a>, the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Box%E2%80%93Anderson_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Box–Anderson test (page does not exist)">Box–Anderson test</a> and the <a href="/w/index.php?title=Moses_test&action=edit&redlink=1" class="new" title="Moses test (page does not exist)">Moses test</a>.
</p><p>Resampling methods, which include the <a href="/wiki/Bootstrapping_(statistics)" title="Bootstrapping (statistics)">bootstrap</a> and the <a href="/wiki/Resampling_(statistics)" title="Resampling (statistics)">jackknife</a>, may be used to test the equality of variances.
</p>
</section><div class="mw-heading mw-heading2 section-heading" onclick="mfTempOpenSection(7)"><span class="indicator mf-icon mf-icon-expand mf-icon--small"></span><h2 id="Moment_of_inertia">Moment of inertia</h2><span class="mw-editsection">
<a role="button" href="/w/index.php?title=Variance&action=edit&section=39" title="Edit section: Moment of inertia" class="cdx-button cdx-button--size-large cdx-button--fake-button cdx-button--fake-button--enabled cdx-button--icon-only cdx-button--weight-quiet ">

<span>edit</span>
</a>

</span>

</div><section class="mf-section-7 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-7">
<link rel="mw-deduplicated-inline-style" href="mw-data:TemplateStyles:r1236090951"><div role="note" class="hatnote navigation-not-searchable">See also: <a href="/wiki/Moment_(physics)#Examples" title="Moment (physics)">Moment (physics) § Examples</a></div>
<p>The variance of a probability distribution is analogous to the  <a href="/wiki/Moment_of_inertia" title="Moment of inertia">moment of inertia</a> in <a href="/wiki/Classical_mechanics" title="Classical mechanics">classical mechanics</a> of a corresponding mass distribution along a line, with respect to rotation about its center of mass.<sup id="cite_ref-pearson_26-0" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pearson-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>  It is because of this analogy that such things as the variance are called <i><a href="/wiki/Moment_(mathematics)" title="Moment (mathematics)">moments</a></i> of <a href="/wiki/Probability_distribution" title="Probability distribution">probability distributions</a>.<sup id="cite_ref-pearson_26-1" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-pearson-26"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>26<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup> The covariance matrix is related to the <a href="/wiki/Moment_of_inertia_tensor" class="mw-redirect" title="Moment of inertia tensor">moment of inertia tensor</a> for multivariate distributions. The moment of inertia of a cloud of <i>n</i> points with a covariance matrix of <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \Sigma }">
  <semantics>
    <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
      <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
        <mi mathvariant="normal">Σ<!-- Σ --></mi>
      </mstyle>
    </mrow>

</div><section class="mf-section-8 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-8">
<p>The <i>semivariance</i> is calculated in the same manner as the variance but only those observations that fall below the mean are included in the calculation:<span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-display mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math display="block" xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle {\text{Semivariance}}={1 \over {n}}\sum _{i:x_{i}<\mu }(x_{i}-\mu )^{2}}">

</div><section class="mf-section-9 collapsible-block" id="mf-section-9">
<p>The term <i>variance</i> was first introduced by <a href="/wiki/Ronald_Fisher" title="Ronald Fisher">Ronald Fisher</a> in his 1918 paper <i><a href="/wiki/The_Correlation_Between_Relatives_on_the_Supposition_of_Mendelian_Inheritance" class="mw-redirect" title="The Correlation Between Relatives on the Supposition of Mendelian Inheritance">The Correlation Between Relatives on the Supposition of Mendelian Inheritance</a></i>:<sup id="cite_ref-28" class="reference"><a href="#cite_note-28"><span class="cite-bracket">[</span>28<span class="cite-bracket">]</span></a></sup>
</p>
<blockquote><p>The great body of available statistics show us that the deviations of a <a href="/wiki/Biometry" class="mw-redirect" title="Biometry">human measurement</a> from its mean follow very closely the <a href="/wiki/Normal_distribution" title="Normal distribution">Normal Law of Errors</a>, and, therefore, that the variability may be uniformly measured by the <a href="/wiki/Standard_deviation" title="Standard deviation">standard deviation</a> corresponding to the <a href="/wiki/Square_root" title="Square root">square root</a> of the <a href="/wiki/Mean_square_error" class="mw-redirect" title="Mean square error">mean square error</a>. When there are two independent causes of variability capable of producing in an otherwise uniform population distributions with standard deviations <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \sigma _{1}}">
  <semantics>
    <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
      <mstyle displaystyle="true" scriptlevel="0">
        <msub>
          <mi>σ<!-- σ --></mi>
          <mrow class="MJX-TeXAtom-ORD">
            <mn>1</mn>
          </mrow>
        </msub>
      </mstyle>
    </mrow>
    <annotation encoding="application/x-tex">{\displaystyle \sigma _{1}}</annotation>
  </semantics>
</math></span><noscript><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7fa0e56273a1cb32709b442e2421e9f947522b84" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; width:2.382ex; height:2.009ex;" alt="{\displaystyle \sigma _{1}}"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 2.382ex;height: 2.009ex;vertical-align: -0.671ex;" data-src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/7fa0e56273a1cb32709b442e2421e9f947522b84" data-alt="{\displaystyle \sigma _{1}}" data-class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert"> </span></span> and <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle \sigma _{2}}">

  </semantics>
</math></span><noscript><img src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8d4b9cd9efc54bcfd04e0a2231913c13f10798d9" class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert" aria-hidden="true" style="vertical-align: -0.671ex; width:2.382ex; height:2.009ex;" alt="{\displaystyle \sigma _{2}}"></noscript><span class="lazy-image-placeholder" style="width: 2.382ex;height: 2.009ex;vertical-align: -0.671ex;" data-src="https://wikimedia.org/api/rest_v1/media/math/render/svg/8d4b9cd9efc54bcfd04e0a2231913c13f10798d9" data-alt="{\displaystyle \sigma _{2}}" data-class="mwe-math-fallback-image-inline mw-invert skin-invert"> </span></span>, it is found that the distribution, when both causes act together, has a standard deviation <span class="mwe-math-element"><span class="mwe-math-mathml-inline mwe-math-mathml-a11y" style="display: none;"><math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" alttext="{\displaystyle {\sqrt {\sigma _{1}^{2}+\sigma _{2}^{2}}}}">
